Name.description: Unique identifier of the credential format

Encoding Scheme.description: Data encoding on the storage layer which applies to this credential format
Encoding Scheme.$comment: can this be set as an enum since the amount of encoding schemes is limited?

allOf.description: Is the credential format able to communicate data or annotations that supports the semantic understanding of the credential data?
allOf.$comment: this sounds like an objective field since semantic is a defined word

allOf.description: Is the credential format capable to cover different cryptographic algorithms without any requirements and achieve cryptographic agility, as demanded by regulations?

Is the credential format capable of selective disclosure - presenting or revealing a subset of claims/attributes - without relying on architecture and protocol solutions like Just-in-Time issuance or a presentation transformation by a trusted third party?
allOf.$comment: Do we need to ask if kind of selective disclosure reveals more information like it should? Like using SD-JWT, the verifier can see that the value came from the same credential like in the past, but this is not the case for Anoncreds

allOf.description: Is the credential Format able to produce general-purpose predicates, that means attestations without revealing the data, e.g. a proof to be over 18 without revealing the date of birth?

Compatibility with Signing Algorithms.description: What signing algorithms can the format be combined with?

Compatibility with Key Management Method.description: What key management methods can the credential format be combined with?

CESR/CESR Proof.Name: CESR/CESR Proof
CESR/CESR Proof.Standardization (Body, Process): IETF (intention to go to Blockchain WG)

Gordian Envelope.Name: Gordian Envelope
Gordian Envelope.Standardization (Body, Process): IETF (for CBOR registration) W3C (for did method and alternative DID document and credentials data format)

MDOC.Name: MDOC
MDOC.Compatibility with Signing Algorithms: ECDSA(NIST and Brainpool curves), EdDSA, RSA

Name.description: The name of the credential profile, as it is commonly called.  This is the name that should be used to refer to the credential profile in other documents and discussions

Credential Profile Description.description: A brief description of the credential profile

allOf.description: The format of the credential.
The format of the signing algorithm.
The format of the status algorithm.
The format of the key management for the issuer.
The format of the key management for the holder.
The format of issuance protocol.
The format of the presentation protocol.
The format of the trust management.

Formal Specification.description: A link to a formal specification of the credential profile.

AnonCreds with did:indy.Name: AnonCreds with did:indy
AnonCreds with did:indy.Credential Profile Description: Well-known default profile in all Hyperledger Indy implementations. A favoured profile due to selective disclosure and predicate capability as well as privacy-preserving revocation mechanism. Standardization in community spec in progress (July 2022).

HAIP.Name: HAIP
HAIP.Credential Profile Description: OpenID4VC High Assurance Interoperability Profile with SD-JWT-VC

IRMA (Yivi) wallet.Name: IRMA (Yivi) wallet
IRMA (Yivi) wallet.Status Algorithm: RSA-B - cryptographic accumulator based on RSA

JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (LDP).Name: JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (LDP)
JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (LDP).Credential Profile Description: Interoperability profile used in the PlugFest2

JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (VC).Name: JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (VC)
JFFLabs x VC-EDU PlugFest2 (VC).Credential Profile Description: Interoperability profile used in the PlugFest2

JSON-LD VCs with BBS (Credential is Secr.Name: JSON-LD VCs with BBS (Credential is Secret)

Description.description: Give more information about this property

Implementation-Support.description: Links to SDKs or documentation how to implement it.
Implementation-Support.$comment: Objective field, only link to resources. Do not explain like 'easy to implement' since this is subjective.

IPR-Policy.description: What is the policy regarding intellectual properties associated with this technology?

Standardization.description: Under which Standardization Body and which standards track/status is it standardized?

Name.description: Unique identifier of the issuance protocol

allOf.description: Is there any infrastructure required to resolve keys and/or validate identifier to key binding?
Can the key referred to in a credential be replaced by another key?

Is it possible to retain and obtain the history of keys related to a certain identifier? In case of key rotation it is important for signed credentials to request older keys that are not used for signing anymore

Party.description: What party may uses this technique?
Party.$comment: We are not looking at verifiers here, since e.g. the identification of the verifier is not part of the credential comparison matrix

did:dyne.Name: did:dyne
did:dyne.IPR Policy: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

Key History.Description: conditional (with OpenID Connect Federation Key History)
conditional (with OpenID Connect Federation Key History)

Name.description: Unique identifier of the presentation protocol
A unique identifier for the signing algorithm

allOf.description: Is the signing algorithm recognized in regulatory frameworks of leading government bodies?

Performance.description: How performant is the signing algorithm?
Performance.$comment: difficult to answer, since there is no performance framework to measure against

allOf.description: Is the Signing Algorithm supported by common hardware-backed cryptographic implementations, such as Secure Elements, SecureEnclave, HSM, Strongbox, TEE, TPM
allOf.$comment: Using different approaches can lead to different results when choosing key lengths or performance measurements

allOf.description: Is the Signing Algorithm capable of creating a credential scheme, such that two verification processes can not be linked/correlated by colluding Verifiers/Relying Parties?

Security strength.description: What level of security strength is common and standardized for this signing algorithm?

allOf.description: Is the Signing Algorithm still secure if quantum computing achieves substantial computation power?

BBS+ with public key binding.Name: BBS+ with public key binding
BBS+ with public key binding.Standardization (Body, Process): DIF (intention to transfer to IRTF CFRG)

BoundBBS+.Name: BoundBBS+
BoundBBS+.Standardization (Body, Process): DIF (intention to transfer to IRTF CFRG)

CL.Name: CL
CL.Specification: CL-Signatures of there own do not have a formal specification, that is included in Anoncreds
CL.Performance: Ursa: up to 7 seconds for a validation and approximately 30 seconds for credential definition generation; IRMA (Yivi): both in less than a second

Recognition by government authorities (N.Description: widely accepted, though still behind ECDSA

PS.Name: PS
PS.Specification: PS-Signatures of there own do not have a formal specification, that is included in Anoncreds-V2
PS.Performance: medium, faster than CL, slower than Schnorr, single-digit milliseconds for all operations, even in a threshold decentralized setting

allOf.description: Is the status algorithm recognized in regulatory frameworks of leading government bodies?

Category.description: Algorithm that behind the implementation of the revocation (Bitlist = each credential has a position in the list. Deny-List: revoked credentials will be added on demand. Accumulator: cryptographic proof the holder presents to show that the credential is not revoked)

Performance.description: How performant is the revocation mechanism (for issuer, holder and verifier)?
Performance.$comment: For this case there could be some king of test framework

allOf.description: Does the Verifier have the possibility to observe the revocation status beyond the presentation?
Does the issuer have possibilities to trace the usage of his issued credentials through the revocation mechanism?
allOf.$comment: With a size of one used element the issuer should always be able to trace the usage of his issued credentials

allOf.description: At what scale has the algorithm/technology been demonstrated to work? Are there any known issues?
Does the revocation mechanism support an authentication if the holder is offline?

Traceability.Description: potentially possible with malicious issuer by providing a revocation list with a single entry

RSA-B - cryptographic accumulator based.Name: RSA-B - cryptographic accumulator based on RSA

Traceability.Description: potentially possible with malicious issuer by providing a revocation list with a single entry

VB20 - cryptographic accumulator based o.Name: VB20 - cryptographic accumulator based on pairings

Name.description: A unique identifier for the trust management approach

Description.description: Explanation or link to a source how this trust management approach works

IRMA (Yivi) Schemes.Name: IRMA (Yivi) Schemes
IRMA (Yivi) Schemes.Description: every issuer publishes its keys at a certain URL, the whole structure is signed by a trusted authority

OpenID Connect Federation.Name: OpenID Connect Federation
OpenID Connect Federation.Description: Uses JWTs and REST APIs to represent trust chains and trust marks

TRAIN.Name: TRAIN
TRAIN.Description: Uses DNS records and ETSI Trusted Lists for trust management, developed in the EU Project NGI ESSIF-Lab, https://train.trust-scheme.de/info/

Verifier knows Issuers.Name: Verifier knows Issuers
Verifier knows Issuers.Description: The verifier knows which issuers he trusts for issuing certain credentials, organizational solution

X.509 certificates.Name: X.509 certificates
X.509 certificates.Description: Trust is managed by way of attributes attested in the certificate (e.g. could be role of an issuer) in combination with trust chains. The ultimate entity in the chain is typically trust anchor recipients need to rely in.
